channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Shatila Journal: Palestinian Refuge for 6 Decades, Now Flooded From Syria
item.description: The Syrian civil war has driven a wave of Syrians into Lebanon, roughly doubling the population of the Palestinian refugee camp of Shatila.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The main market in the Shatila refugee camp, one of two such rapidly growing settlements on the edge of Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: Russian Gas Pipeline Will Go Through Turkey, Not Bulgaria
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said South Stream, a major project to deliver natural gas to Europe, was plagued by pressure from the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Harassed on a Bus in India, Sisters Lash Out and Video Goes Viral
item.description: They kicked, pushed and punched one of the harassers so aggressively that another man on the bus had to come to his aid, although no one aided the sisters.
item.dc:creator: By POH SI TENG

item.title: Maoist Rebels Kill 13 Members of a Police Force in India
item.description: The members of the Central Reserve Police Force were killed in an ambush in a forested area of the central state of Chhattisgarh.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: Palestinian Woman Attacked Israeli Man in West Bank
item.description: The woman stabbed and lightly wounded an Israeli man at a hitchhiking stop before she was shot and wounded by Israeli soldiers at the scene.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: International Aid Agencies Call for Temporary Exit From Afghanistan
item.description: Citing Taliban attacks in Kabul in the last three weeks, several agencies have said that although they want to stay, the current situation is too dangerous.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Video Feature: Targeting ISIS’ Black-Market Oil Trade
item.description: Control of black-market oil is said to be the backbone of the Islamic State’s financing and logistical support.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By EMILY B. HAGER

item.title: World Food Program, Short on Money, Says It Will Suspend Aid to Syrians
item.description: The agency said the suspension, taking place immediately, will have “disastrous” consequences for refugees struggling to cope with deprivation.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Dozens Missing After South Korean Trawler Sinks in Bering Sea
item.description: Rescuers had managed to pull seven survivors and one dead crew member out of the water after the 1,753-ton vessel Oryong 501 sank.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Gregarious and Direct: China’s Web Doorkeeper
item.description: Lu Wei, as the country’s new Internet czar, is the ambassador of a policy in which Beijing claims the right to censor content and track users.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL MOZUR and JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Lu Wei has ratcheted up China’s sophisticated system of online censorship.

item.title: Hong Kong Protesters, Despite Clashes and Setbacks, Remain Committed
item.description: Demonstrations may soon end as the police whittle away at the main protest area and as students, pro-democracy lawmakers and academics wrangle over how to proceed.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Alois Brunner, Long-Sought Nazi, Is Said to Have Died 4 Years Ago in Syria
item.description: Mr. Brunner was Adolf Eichmann’s “right-hand man” and responsible for the deportation of 128,500 Jews to death camps, a top Nazi hunter said.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Pro-Europe Parties Set to Control Moldova Parliament, Early Tally Shows
item.description: Shadowed by the violence in neighboring Ukraine, the vote became another fierce contest between the West and Russia for influence in a former Soviet republic.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Teachers’ Strikes Spread Across Northeast China
item.description: The strikes over low salaries and mandatory payments to pension plans began last week and now encompass a half-dozen cities or counties.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: China Says It Will Deny British Parliament Members Entry to Hong Kong
item.description: The lawmakers had signaled they were going to look into the handling of the pro-democracy protests.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Is the Cyprus Issue Insoluble?
item.description: Despite new dangers, decades of separation seem to have worn away at the desire to fix the problem.
item.dc:creator: By NIKOS KONSTANDARAS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Growing Up Fearful in Nigeria
item.description: Murderous rampages by Muslims and Christians have swept the north for decades.
item.dc:creator: By UKAMAKA OLISAKWE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: The Scene as Police Sent Protesters Fleeing in Hong Kong
item.description: A semblance of calm returned to the city’s streets on Monday after a tense and at times frightening night, with numerous pro-democracy protesters and police officers injured as both sides vied for control of a road along the main government offices.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: China Refuses to Grant Hong Kong Visas to British Lawmakers
item.description: The members of Parliament had signaled they were going to look into the handling of the pro-democracy protests.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Conservationists Continue Push to Block Hong Kong Ivory Sales
item.description: Protesters gathered Saturday outside a Hong Kong department store that had been prominently selling ivory products, part of an effort to publicize the city’s key role in the trade.
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A Hong Kong police officer stood inside the Chinese Goods Center, a store that sells African elephant ivory products, as animal welfare and wildlife conservation advocates protested outside against alleged illegal ivory trade.
